reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 14, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars The Allon We’ve All Come to Know and Love is Back
reviews.reviewText: After the Cellist, the new left me and others disappointed. The Collector has the same cleverness and adventure back, leaving me anxious for the next chapter in the life of Gabriel Allon, art restorer and occasional savior of the world, in a believable way.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 13, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Another page turner.
reviews.reviewText: Typical Daniel Silva. Never disappoints. Can’t wait for the next one. Keeps up with the times.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 27, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Another strong entry in the mini-saga Allon vs. Russia’s latest tsar
reviews.reviewText: Gabriel Allon has been enjoying his retirement from the Office in Venice with his family for a few months. He is restoring an altarpiece that is beneath his skills, but pays the bills. One morning, General Ferreti of Rome’s Art Squad pays a visit to ask Gabriel to help him authenticate a painting by Van Gogh that has recently resurfaced in the palazzo of a South African emigré that has been killed on the Amalfi Coast.Gabriel rightly attributes the painting to Van Gogh, but wonders what could possibly have happened for a thief to leave such a valuable piece behind. The obvious conclusion seems to be that another painting, even more valuable, with the same dimensions, was the target of the heist. And so starts an investigation that moves through the usual European capitals, and this time Denmark, then Russia and Finland, to find the woman who had access to the late South African magnate’s vault during the night, ably disabling his state-of-the-art security system and getting away with a coveted painting. Gabriel is sure she didn’t kill the man, but she may be the next target—if the untimely death of the middle man, a rare books dealer, is any indication.A novel in four parts, The Collector is Silva once again returning close to top form. There’s significantly less padding than in most of his other books, and significantly less pages to read as well, so it feels less than padding and more like the welcomed backstories on recurring characters and the operations they have been involved in that they are supposed to be. The Collector is page-turning and easy to read, with fascinating Van Gogh’s and Vermeer’s details, as well as the story behind the heist at the Isabella Gardner Museum in Boston. Refreshing as well are Irene’s views on climate change (my kind of girl!)His best works have been set in Russia and, as always, this one delivers in spades; the brutality of Russia’s security services and the Russian elite lends well to a novel with the fate of the world at stake. While I don’t agree with the all the politics laid out in the book regarding the Russo-Ukrainian War since that conflagration is a disaster of the West’s making— Russia oddly playing defense—, I share the sentiment that Mr. Putin isn’t going to go quietly into the night. I agree though, that the nuclear option is starting to look like a much too scary possibility. We must be careful what we wish for, Russia does not respond well to anything other than a strong man, and the amount of nuclear weapons they possess does not lend well to instability or a puppet government with questionable alliances. Just saying…Besides the politics, which I disagree on for the reasons above explained, The Collector is yet another strong entry in the mini-saga of Gabriel Allon vs. Russia’s latest tsar. Entertaining, easy to read, and scarily possible make this entry not to be missed.

reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Every Daniel Silva’s book is spectacular
reviews.reviewText: I was reading this book on my Kindle but I prefer to have the book itself so I’ve got my hard cover book

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 7, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Tried so hard to read slowly
reviews.reviewText: But of course I couldn't. Fast paced, exciting, no boring interludes. Great writing, and continued evolution and aging of characters. My favorite series of all time.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 25, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars a really great read!
reviews.reviewText: This book will not let you down - it wraps you up and takes you along on a wonderful journey - and just when you think you know how it will end, you MUST keep reading!ENJOY!! I know I did.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 1, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Before its too late
reviews.reviewText: Eventually we must all stand for something. Whether as a leader or a follower we must choose wisely. The writer had his characters choose wisely before it was too late.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 9, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Another great book
reviews.reviewText: I can’t wait until he produces another book.
I read this book in record time. The plot is quite believable and very timely with developments in Ukraine. I never tire of reading Daniel Silvia’s books
Adoro a série de livros do personagem Gabriel Allon, li todos. Sempre uma leitura que prende sem cair na mesmice de um personagem de uma série tão longa.
Connecting fact and fiction brilliantly as usual. Daniel Silva has created another masterpiece thriller based on Mossad agent , Gabriel Allon

Seguo Daniel Silva da alcuni anni, ho letto tutti i suoi libri della serie Gabriel Allon (eccetto uno) e 4 romani fa (dunque circa 4 anni fa) mi ero rassegnata a rinunciare a Gabriel Allon, perchè i romanzi erano diventati troppo "copia incolla" e alla fine perfino noiosi. Poi hi riprovato qualche mese fa con Portrait of an unknown Woman e... evviva! Il miglior Daniel Silva è tornato!! Un mese fa ho letto The Collector e ancora una volta confermo: Daniel Silva è tornato alla sua miglior forma.Forse l'ambito dell'arte, del commercio illegale di beni culturali, del problema delle restituzioni di opere sottratte dai nazisti è un ambito che gli è particolarmente congeniale. Sta di fatto che ho "divorato" il libro in 2 giorni. Per cui, chi ha amato Daniel Silva e Gabriel Allon prima maniera, apprezzerà anche questo. Unica annotazione: ho letto la versione in inglese, non la traduzione in italiano.Buona lettura!
As all of mr Daniel Silva's booksLooking forward to more of the same.Thank you for this enjoyable story.
